story.iWant: a properly structured Next.js project with core dependencies configured
story.soThat: I have a solid foundation to build features efficiently
story.tasks: - Initialize Next.js Project (npx create-next-app with TypeScript, Tailwind, App Router, ESLint) - Verify Project Structure (check directories: app/, public/, node_modules/, config files) - Create Additional Folder Structure (mkdir components/, lib/, types/) - Configure Absolute Imports (verify tsconfig.json paths with @/* alias) - Initialize Git Repository (git init, verify .gitignore) - Test Local Development Server (npm run dev, verify localhost:3000) - Set Up Vercel Project (npx vercel link - optional but recommended) - Configure Prettier (install prettier, create .prettierrc and .prettierignore - optional but recommended)

story-context.acceptanceCriteria: - Next.js 14+ with App Router initialized - TypeScript configuration present and working - Tailwind CSS setup and functional - ESLint and Prettier configured - Git repository with proper .gitignore - Project runs locally with `npm run dev` - Basic folder structure exists: /app, /components, /lib, /types - Absolute imports configured with @/* alias

doc.title: Technical Architecture
doc.snippet: Use Next.js 14+ with App Router as the primary framework. Full-stack framework with built-in API routes, excellent Vercel integration, image optimization, server/client components. Initialize with: npx create-next-app@latest wagnerbeef --typescript --tailwind --app --eslint

doc.title: Technical Architecture
doc.snippet: Use Tailwind CSS for styling with shadcn/ui for components. Tailwind provides utility-first rapid development with small bundle size. shadcn/ui components are copy-paste (not a dependency), accessible by default (WCAG 2.1 AA), and customizable with Tailwind.

doc.title: Technical Architecture
doc.snippet: App Router structure: /app with (auth), (public), (dashboard) route groups. Shared components in /components with ui/ subdirectory for shadcn/ui components. Layout components include header, footer, and dashboard-nav.

doc.title: Epic Breakdown
doc.snippet: Story 1.1 establishes the technical foundation for wagnerBeef. Use create-next-app with TypeScript and Tailwind, configure absolute imports with @/ alias, set up Vercel project for deployment, initialize Git repository.

node.package: Full-stack React framework with App Router

story-context.constraints: - Must use Next.js 14+ with App Router (not Pages Router) - Must use TypeScript for all code (no JavaScript files) - Must use Tailwind CSS for styling (no CSS modules or styled-components) - Must configure absolute imports with @/* alias - Project must run successfully with npm run dev - All configuration files must be properly initialized - Git repository must be initialized with proper .gitignore - Follow Next.js best practices and conventions - Ensure development server starts without errors

tests.standards: This is a project initialization story. Testing focuses on verification rather than automated tests: - Verify all required directories exist - Verify all configuration files are present and valid - Verify development server starts successfully - Verify TypeScript compilation works - Verify ESLint runs without errors - Verify Tailwind CSS is functional - Verify hot reload works
tests.locations: No test files for this story. Future stories will add tests in: - __tests__/ directory for unit tests - e2e/ directory for end-to-end tests (if needed)
tests.ideas: Manual verification checklist (from story Definition of Done): - AC-1: Run `npm run dev` and verify server starts without errors - AC-2: Open browser to http://localhost:3000 and verify Next.js welcome page displays - AC-3: Run `npm run lint` and verify ESLint passes - AC-4: Edit app/page.tsx with TypeScript error and verify compilation catches it - AC-5: Add Tailwind classes to app/page.tsx and verify styles apply - AC-6: Edit app/page.tsx and verify hot reload updates browser - AC-7: Verify all directories exist: app/, components/, lib/, types/, public/ - AC-8: Verify tsconfig.json contains paths configuration with @/* alias
